facts.text: Learned Additional Sessions Judge, Monghyr convicted Ramchandra Chaudhary (appellant in Cr. App. No. 177 of 1961) under s. 302 IPC; convicted Baleshwar Rai alias Nepali Master (appellant in this appeal) and Jogendra Chaudhary (appellant in Cr. App. No. 178 of 1961) under s. 302 read with s. 34 IPC; sentenced each to death.
Appeals dismissed by Patna High Court; death sentences confirmed.

On March 17, 1959 at about 8.00 p.m., chaukidars of village Fateha assembled in crime centre: Anandi Paswan (deceased), Misri Paswan PW2, Baleshwar Paswan PW3, Narain Paswan; Anandi and Misri lying on chouki with weapons (bhala, muretha, pharsa); others lying on ground.
Crime centre in dalan of Tilak Chaudhary PW6; Srilal Chaudhary PW7 (brother of Tilak) lying on khatia north-east; in adjacent room PW11 Nathuni Chaudhary alias Durga Das and PW12 Ramchander Jha.

A little before 9.00 p.m., someone called out 'Darogaji'; deceased Anandi Paswan and Misri Paswan got up; moonlit night; saw Ramchandra Chaudhary, Jogendra Chaudhary and Nepali Master standing closeby.

Jogendra Chaudhary and Nepali Master caught deceased Anandi; Ramchandra Chaudhary caught Misri Paswan; Ramchandra and Jogendra had guns slung across shoulders; took them to east road running north-south, proceeded southward; no cry due to threat of shooting.

Reached place west of Peare Sao's house and east of Rampratap Tanti PW5's house; deceased called for Rampratap's help, freed himself, ran westward; Ramchandra let go Misri and fired at deceased; Misri ran into Peare Sao's house, heard second gun shot.

Misri detected by Mst. Ajo PW8 (wife of Peare Sao), forced to leave; concealed behind door; after moon set, went to Fakir Paswan PW4's house east of Peare Sao's, narrated incident mentioning Ramchandra and Jogendra.

Early morning March 18, 1959, Misri went to scene, found Anandi dead in ditch by road, face downwards, two gun shot wounds on back; contacted Narain and Baleshwar Paswan, left them with body, went to PS with Ramdeo (son of deceased), lodged FIR.
Junior Sub-Inspector commenced investigation, submitted charge-sheet against three appellants on March 15, 1959.
Motive: Appellants veteran criminals; chaukidars reported movements; deceased helped Dalsingsarai police arrest Motia Mushar (ploughman of Ramchandra) in dacoity case.
All appellants denied participation; defence: false case concocted by police.

Main evidence: PW2 Misri Paswan named Ramchandra and Jogendra in FIR; Nepali initially unknown; Ramchandra and Jogendra identified by Misri plus five others (Narain Paswan, Rampratap Tanti PW5, Srilal Chaudhary PW7, Nathuni Chaudhary PW11, Ramchander Jha PW12).
Nepali Master identified by PW7 Srilal Chaudhary and PW9 Dukhi Mahto at test identification parade.

Ext.6: Anonymous letter to Senior SI Kashi Nath PW22 admitting motive ('rascal Anandia Choukidar spoiled the life of that poor Mushar... spied against us'); Ext.3 dated June 9, 1959 in handwriting of Nepali Master; handwriting expert opined Ext.3 tallies with Ext.6.
At incident, Ramchandra said 'his servant Motia was taken away forcibly'; Jogendra sarcastically asked deceased 'Where is your military today?'

legal_issues.text: Whether common intention to commit murder under s.302/34 IPC established against all three appellants, particularly Jogendra Chaudhary and Nepali Master.
Whether identification of Nepali Master reliable, given identification by two witnesses and test ID held long after arrest.
Whether Ext.6 admissible under s.21 Evidence Act and not barred by s.162 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Common intention to commit murder not established for Jogendra Chaudhary.
Nepali Master identified only by one witness at test ID (others did not turn up); not legally permissible to base conviction on single identification.
Srilal Chaudhary PW7 is 75 years old with weak eyesight; evidence unreliable.
Test identification held long after arrest; evidence of identifiers not believable.
Ext.6 hit by s.162 CrPC as received by Sub-Inspector during investigation.

respondent_arguments.text: Eyewitness evidence of PW2 Misri Paswan and five others reliable; accepted by Sessions Judge and High Court.
Common intention inferred from coming together armed with guns, motive (grievance against Anandi for reporting and arrest of Motia), statements at scene.
Nepali identified by two witnesses PW7 and PW9; single truthful witness sufficient.
Ext.6 in handwriting of Nepali (per expert); admissible under s.21 Evidence Act as admission; not hit by s.162 CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: Eyewitness evidence naming and identifying appellants accepted by Sessions Judge (who saw witnesses) and High Court; cannot be reappraised in special leave appeals.
Common intention inferred: all three came together; two with guns; motive established (Anandi reported movements, helped arrest Motia); statements at scene confirm revenge intent shared by all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No doubt on common intention for murder.

court_reasoning.text: Even single truthful witness sufficient for conviction; here Nepali identified by two (PW7, PW9); PW7's age/eyesight assessed and believed by lower courts.
Test ID delay considered but rejected due to Ext.6 corroboration; Ext.6 admitted portion shows motive, in Nepali's handwriting per expert.
s.162 CrPC bars statements made to police in course of investigation; Ext.6 is communication de hors enquiry, not ascribable to investigating officer's enquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Document not hit by s.162 CrPC.

holdings.text: Eyewitness evidence reliable; cannot reappraise in special leave appeals.
Common intention to commit murder under s.302/34 IPC established against all three appellants.
Identification of Nepali Master reliable, corroborated by Ext.6.
Ext.6 admissible under s.21 Evidence Act; not barred by s.162 CrPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction for murder and common intention.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Does not bar Ext.6 as not statement in course of investigation.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds convictions under s.302 and s.302/34 IPC and death sentences confirmed by Patna High Court; dismisses appeals by special leave.

key_quotes.text: "The rascal Anandia Choukidar spoiled the life of that poor Mushar by instigating the S.I. of Police of Dalsingsarai and subsequently he also spied against us for nothing."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Admission of motive in Ext.6, in Nepali's handwriting, corroborates prosecution case.

key_quotes.text: Ramchandra said 'his servant Motia was taken away forcibly' and Jogendra asked 'Where is your military today?'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms common intention for revenge murder.

key_quotes.text: Section 162 is aimed at statements recorded by a police officer while investigating into an offence... A communication like Ext. 6 will not fall within the ambit of such statements.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of s.162 CrPC; holds Ext.6 admissible.
